message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient’s leg position suggests a hip dislocation with an associated fracture. The sensory and motor deficits are most likely to be paresis and numbness of the medial thigh and medial side of the calf, and weak hip flexion and knee extension. This is due to injury to the obturator nerve, which runs through the pelvis and along the medial aspect of the femur, and is often damaged in anterior hip dislocations. Option (B) refers to injury to the obturator nerve, but only presents numbness and inability to adduct the thigh without weakness. Option (C) refers to injury to the ilioinguinal nerve, which is not likely in this case. Option (D) refers to injury to the sciatic nerve, which is not likely in anterior hip dislocations.

We refer to orthopedic and neurology resources for help. The hip flexor (iliopsoas) and knee extensor (quadriceps) muscles may be injured due to the dislocation and fracture, leading to paresis and weakness. The medial thigh and medial side of the calf are supplied by the femoral nerve, which may also be injured during the trauma. This matches option A. Option B describes the obturator nerve, which is responsible for hip adduction and sensory innervation of the medial thigh. Option C describes the genitofemoral nerve, which supplies the skin of the scrotum and upper medial thigh. Option D describes injury to the common peroneal nerve, which supplies the muscles of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot, leading to foot drop and sensory loss in specific areas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The right anterior hip dislocation indicated involvement of the obturator nerve, which innervates the medial thigh and medial calf, resulting in paresis and numbness. Weakness of hip flexion and knee extension suggests involvement of the femoral nerve, which also innervates the muscles. Therefore, option (A) is the correct answer. Option (B) describes sensory and motor deficits associated with obturator nerve injury but not femoral nerve injury. Option (C) describes sensory deficits associated with ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric nerve injury but not femoral nerve injury. Option (D) describes sensory and motor deficits associated with common peroneal nerve injury but not femoral nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the description of the patient's injury and the anatomical locations affected by the dislocation and fracture, option A is the most likely. The obturator nerve provides sensory innervation to the medial thigh and medial calf and motor innervation to the hip flexors and knee extensors, which can be affected by the injury. The other options refer to nerves that are not likely to be affected by the specific injury described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The femoral nerve is most commonly injured with anterior hip dislocations and femoral head fractures. This nerve provides innervation to the hip flexors, knee extensors, and sensation to the medial thigh and medial side of the calf. Thus, the patient is likely to experience paresis and numbness in these areas, as well as weak hip flexion and knee extension. Choices B, C, and D are not consistent with femoral nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An anterior hip dislocation typically damages the obturator nerve, which supplies the medial thigh and medial side of the calf, leading to paresis and numbness in those areas. In addition, the femoral nerve, which supplies hip flexion and knee extension, may also be damaged, resulting in weak hip flexion and knee extension. Option B describes the sensory and motor deficits for obturator nerve damage alone, while option C describes the sensory and motor deficits for ilioinguinal nerve damage. Option D describes the sensory and motor deficits for common peroneal nerve damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An anterior hip dislocation can result in damage to the sciatic nerve, which would cause paresis and numbness of the medial thigh and medial side of the calf, as well as weak hip flexion and knee extension. The other options do not match the nerve distribution that would be affected by a hip dislocation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on the anatomy of the lower extremity for help. The dislocation and fracture suggest that the obturator nerve and femoral nerve are likely affected. These nerves innervate the muscles responsible for hip flexion, knee extension, and sensation to the medial thigh and medial side of the calf. Option A describes these deficits. Option B describes deficits of the femoral nerve, which is not likely affected in this case. Option C describes deficits of the ilioinguinal nerve, which is also not likely affected. Option D describes deficits of the common peroneal nerve, which is not likely affected in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s injury involves the femoral nerve, which provides innervation to the medial thigh and medial side of the calf, as well as hip flexors and knee extensors. Thus, option A is the correct answer. Option B is incorrect as it describes deficits associated with obturator nerve involvement. Option C is incorrect as it describes deficits associated with genitofemoral nerve involvement. Option D is incorrect as it describes deficits associated with common peroneal nerve involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An anterior hip dislocation can damage the obturator nerve, which innervates the medial thigh and medial calf, causing paresis and numbness in those areas. The femoral nerve, which is responsible for hip flexion and knee extension, can also be damaged, leading to weakness in those movements. Option B describes symptoms of an obturator nerve injury without the femoral nerve involvement. Option C describes symptoms of a genitofemoral nerve injury, which is less common with anterior hip dislocation. Option D describes symptoms of a common peroneal nerve injury, which is not relevant to this case.
